title: Anticrepuscular rays
text:
Anticrepuscular rays, or antisolar rays, are <a href="meteorological%20optics">meteorological</a> <a href="optical%20phenomenon">optical phenomena</a> similar to <a href="crepuscular%20rays">crepuscular rays</a>, but appear opposite of the <a href="Sun">Sun</a> in the <a href="sky">sky</a>. Anticrepuscular rays are essentially <a href="parallel%20%28geometry%29">parallel</a>, but appear to converge toward the <a href="antisolar%20point">antisolar point</a>, the <a href="vanishing%20point">vanishing point</a>, due to a <a href="visual%20illusion">visual illusion</a> from <a href="linear%20perspective">linear perspective</a>.
Anticrepuscular rays are most frequently visible around <a href="sunrise">sunrise</a> or <a href="sunset">sunset</a>. This is because the atmospheric <a href="light%20scattering%20by%20particles">light scattering</a> that makes them visible (<a href="backscatter">backscatter</a>ing) is larger for low angles to the horizon than most other angles. Anticrepuscular rays are dimmer than crepuscular rays because backscattering is less than <a href="forward%20scatter">forward scatter</a>ing. 
Anticrepuscular rays can be continuous with crepuscular rays, curving across the whole sky in <a href="great%20circle">great circle</a>s.
Mountain shadow.
A common example of a single anticrepuscular ray is provided by the shadow of a mountain at sunset, when viewed from the summit. It appears to be triangular, whatever the shape of the mountain, with the apex at the antisolar point.
Wagon-wheel spokes.
Anticrepuscular rays are sometimes seen enclosed by a rainbow. In this case they can be called "wagon-wheel spokes".
